Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Statistical mechanics of superconductors and other macroscopic phenomena
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will work on problems related to the statistical mechanics of quantum systems and spin models for ferromagnets and superconductors. A fundamental problem in mathematical physics is to explain macroscopic phenomena from the first principles of interacting microscopic particles. This project will build on previous results of the PI and collaborators on the statistical mechanics of Bose-Einstein condensation and the Gross-Pitaevskii equation, Gibbs measures for quantum systems, spin models of ferromagnetism, and probabilistic algorithms for family pedigree relationships. The proposed problems include developing a new Stein's method for quantum many-body systems; extending recent methods to other questions such as large deviations for quantum systems; studying metastability in XY and related models; formulating new spin models of superconductivity and analyzing their properties; and finding connections to the phenomenological theories of Ginzburg-Landau and Gross-Pitaevskii. The PI will integrate her research expertise into probability courses and train students in analytical and computational techniques valuable for a variety of careers. The PI will also continue her interest in encouraging women and other underrepresented groups in math.

There are fundamental challenges in the mathematical physics of condensed matter, the cool and unusual phases of matter near absolute zero that have important applications in physics and engineering. One is to understand how the unique properties of condensed matter emerge from the large-scale interaction of many microscopic particles. Superconductors, for instance, allow current to flow freely with no loss and can expel magnetic fields; superconducting magnets are used in particle accelerators and MRI machines. Mathematical physicists would like to explain these phenomena (and the associated equations) starting from microscopic quantum many-body systems, but to do so, will need innovative mathematical tools developed at the interface between mathematics and physics. The main goals of this project are to develop such tools, to formulate new models with interesting phase transitions, and to find connections to phenomenological theories. Other goals are to strengthen ties with physics and engineering for mutual benefit, integrating research expertise into probability courses, and training students in analytical and computational techniques valuable for a variety of careers. The PI will also continue her interest in encouraging women and other underrepresented groups in math.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project have been to understand how the large-scale behaviors of systems in physics or biology relate to their small-scale properties.

Of particular interest are quantum systems with striking macroscopic properties, such as the magnetic levitation of superconductors and the visible-to-the-naked-eye quantum states of Bose-Einstein condensates. (By contrast, most quantum states are microscopic and difficult to observe.) To get at a better understanding of these phenomena, we have studied spin models, which provide mathematical models of magnets and superconductors, and we have analyzed physical quantities like magnetization which give information about how a spin system responds when it is put into an external magnetic field and how two magnetic effects may interact with each other. We also did numerical simulations of these spin models, finding new metastable states in a two-dimensional superconductor model and analyzing the physical quantities for a three-dimensional magnetic model. Our theoretical results also include a four-dimensional model that should improve our understanding of the Higgs boson. 

To better understand the motion of a quantum particle in organic polymers such as protein or DNA strands, we have studied nonlocal nonlinear Schroedinger equation models and demonstrated rigorously that these models accurately capture the behavior of the microscopic quantum system. We proved a theorem about the macroscopic equations of motion for the mean position and momentum of these systems, and we used computational techniques to study how a quantum particle on an organic polymer can start out with a neat distribution but then quickly turn into a complicated-looking and disorganized distribution that may indicate turbulence.
 
We also studied the motion of a quantum particle in a random field, and compared the continuous-space setting to the discrete-space setting, which turn out to have very different observable properties. This might give physicists a way of figuring out whether space is truly continuous or actually discrete, down at the tiny Planck length-scale which we probably cannot observe directly. Specifically, if space is continuous, then our mathematical results indicate that we should observe faster (called superballistic) motion of a quantum particle through a random field; if space is discrete, we should observe slower (diffusive) motion of the particle.
 
Some more abstract work was done on non-commutative random variables in certain quantum groups (which may model certain properties of heavy atoms and which may be linked to quantum gravity). We constructed a new model of freely independent random variables and proved central-limit-type results for them, that their statistical fluctuations are normal. We also connected these new models to free Araki-Woods factors, which are some of the most challenging von Neumann algebras to understand. 
 
We also built on prior fundamental results about Bose-Einstein Condensation (BEC), to prove a technical probability result, a large deviation principle, for BEC from the first principles of quantum many-body systems. This result may combine with the following dark matter result in future work described below.
 
During the project, the goals expanded in some cool new directions, including studying an important model of dark matter as a BEC of hypothetical particles called axions. We obtained estimates for the amount of time that axions would need to condense like a BEC into a dark matter minicluster, such as what may have happened in early galaxy formation. Specifically, these particles could indeed condense together within the lifetime of the universe. And we determined that one of the aspects of axions that is traditionally neglected may actually affect the condensation time in some situations.
 
The future work would be based on the idea that a large deviation principle sheds light on the most likely rare events. This means that we may be able to predict exactly the rarity of galaxies with no dark matter. Specifically, because observations about dark-matter-free galaxies are starting to accumulate, we may be able to verify theoretically what fraction of galaxies have never had any dark matter, as distinguished from the ones that have lost their dark matter. 
 
Biological machines, especially nano-scale enzymes and ribosomes have also been of interest. Modeling them as information channels, we demonstrate mathematically that they have information processing capacities that allow high-speed and high-accuracy operation, consistent with observed function. Defining rigorously a notion of biological computation has been important, too, as is demonstrating that certain biological systems satisfy this definition, including the cardiovascular system, the Venus flytrap, and the dendrite of a neuron. This forms the foundation for a new model of computation which is significantly different from digital computation, and which should be more compatible with the computational abilities of neurons and brains, providing a better basis for modeling and mimicking nervous systems.
